skill.name: flutter-animations
skill.description: Comprehensive guide for implementing animations in Flutter. Use when adding motion and visual effects to Flutter apps: implicit animations (AnimatedContainer, AnimatedOpacity, TweenAnimationBuilder), explicit animations (AnimationController, Tween, AnimatedWidget/AnimatedBuilder), hero animations (shared element transitions), staggered animations (sequential/overlapping), and physics-based animations. Includes workflow for choosing the right animation type, implementation patterns, and best practices for performance and user experience.
skill.summary: Comprehensive guide for implementing animations in Flutter. Use when adding motion and visual effect...
skill.author: madteacher

security_audit.summary: All 602 static findings are false positives. The patterns flagged as 'certificate/key files' are Flutter widget key parameters. 'Weak cryptographic algorithms' refer to animation curve names like Curves.easeIn. 'External commands' are markdown code blocks. 'System reconnaissance' is Flutter SystemChrome API for display configuration. No network, filesystem, or environment access detected. This is a safe educational/reference skill for Flutter animations.

content.value_statement: Learn to create smooth, performant animations in Flutter apps using implicit, explicit, hero, staggered, and physics-based animation techniques.
actual_capabilities: Create explicit animations with AnimationController, Tween, and AnimatedBuilder
Build hero animations for shared element transitions between screens
Design staggered animations with sequential or overlapping effects
Apply physics-based animations using spring and friction simulations
limitations: Does not provide pre-built animation libraries or packages
Does not generate complete app code from specifications
Does not include platform-specific native animation APIs
Skill provides documentation and guidance, not executable code

use_cases.title: Mobile Developer Learning Animations
use_cases.description: A Flutter developer learning how to add polish to their apps with smooth animations

use_cases.title: UI/UX Designer Implementation
use_cases.description: A designer wanting to understand how to implement animation designs in Flutter code

use_cases.title: Code Assistant Reference
use_cases.description: An AI coding assistant using this skill to help generate correct animation code
use_cases.target_user: Claude Code, Codex, or similar AI tools

prompt_templates.title: Basic Implicit Animation
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to animate a container size and color change in Flutter using an implicit animation.
prompt_templates.scenario: You want a simple animation when a widget property changes

prompt_templates.title: Custom Explicit Animation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Flutter animation that fades in a logo with a bounce effect using AnimationController.
prompt_templates.scenario: You need precise control over animation lifecycle and status

prompt_templates.title: Hero Screen Transition
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement a hero animation in Flutter that transitions an image from a list to a detail screen.
prompt_templates.scenario: You want shared element transitions between routes

prompt_templates.title: Physics-Based Spring Animation
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a spring physics animation to a draggable widget in Flutter using SpringSimulation.
prompt_templates.scenario: You need natural, physics-based motion for gestures

output_examples.input: How do I animate a container color change?
output: Use AnimatedContainer for automatic interpolation when properties change.
Example: AnimatedContainer(duration: Duration(milliseconds: 300), color: _isActive ? Colors.blue : Colors.red)
No AnimationController needed - the widget handles interpolation automatically.

output_examples.input: What is the difference between implicit and explicit animations?
output: Implicit: Triggered by property changes, automatic interpolation, less code (AnimatedContainer).
Explicit: Full manual control via AnimationController, more code but complete control over lifecycle.
Choose implicit for simple property changes, explicit for complex multi-stage animations.

best_practices: Always set explicit duration and curve for animations to avoid unexpected behavior
Dispose AnimationController in the dispose() method to prevent memory leaks
Use Curves.easeInOut for smooth, natural-feeling animations in most cases
anti_patterns: Using explicit animations when implicit would suffice (unnecessary complexity)
Forgetting to dispose AnimationController (causes memory leaks)
Setting animation durations too short (janky) or too long (user frustration)

faq.question: When should I use implicit vs explicit animations?
faq.answer: Use implicit animations when animating single properties triggered by state changes. Use explicit when you need full control over animation lifecycle, multiple properties, or need to react to animation status changes.

faq.question: How do I make animations accessible?
faq.answer: Respect the system's reduced motion preference using WidgetsBinding.instance.window.platformDispatcher.viewConfiguration.accessibilityFeatures.reduceMotion to disable or reduce animations for users who prefer less motion.

faq.question: What is the best curve for a smooth animation?
faq.answer: Curves.easeInOut is the most common choice for smooth animations. Use Curves.easeOut for elements appearing, Curves.easeIn for elements disappearing, and Curves.elasticOut for playful bounce effects.

faq.question: How do I animate between two different widgets?
faq.answer: Use AnimatedSwitcher for cross-fade transitions between widgets, or use TweenAnimationBuilder with a custom tween for more complex interpolations between different widget types.

faq.question: What is a hero animation in Flutter?
faq.answer: A hero animation creates a shared element transition where a widget (typically an image) appears to 'fly' from one screen to another. Use the Hero widget with the same tag on both source and destination widgets.

faq.question: How do I create a staggered list animation?
faq.answer: Use an AnimationController with multiple Interval objects, or use Flutter's StaggeredAnimations package. Each child gets a delayed start based on its index, creating a cascading effect.
